facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court by certificate granted by High Court at Patna

anchor.surface_text: Gajendragadkar, J. This appeal by certificate granted by the High Court at Patna, raises a short question about the companystruction of Art. 9 in Sch. I of Court Fees Act VII of 1870

facts.text: Proceeding instituted against appellant Bibhuti Bhusan Chatterjee under s.107 CrPC in Magistrate First Class Bhagalpur

anchor.surface_text: A proceeding was instituted against the appellant, Bibhuti Bhusan Chatterjee, under s. 107 of the Code of Criminal Procedure in the Court of the Magistrate of First Class at Bhagalpur

facts.text: Magistrate directed appellant to execute bond of Rs.5000 with two sureties of like amount to keep peace for one year

anchor.surface_text: in this proceeding the learned magistrate directed the appellant to execute a bond of Rs. 5,000 with two sureties of the like amount each to keep the peace for a period of one year.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Additional Sessions Judge Bhagalpur, appeal dismissed

anchor.surface_text: The appellant challenged this order by his appeal before the Additional Session Judge at Bhagalpur. The appellate judge agreed with the decision of the learned magistrate and the appeal preferred by the appellant was dismissed.

facts.text: Appellant filed Criminal Revision Application No.924 of 1957 in Patna High Court

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then took this matter before the High Court at Patna by his Criminal Revision Application No. 924 of 1957. It appears that the certified companyies of the orders passed by the two companyrts below

facts.text: Certified copies of orders from two lower courts filed without court fees

anchor.surface_text: in the present proceedings had been filed by the appellant along with his revisional application without any companyrt fees. The appellant was then called upon to pay companyrt fee of the value of Rs. 52.75

facts.text: High Court called upon appellant to pay court fee of Rs.52.75 and Rs.50.75 on the two orders

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was then called upon to pay companyrt fee of the value of Rs. 52.75 and Rs. 50.75 nP. on the two order respectively. The appellant questioned the validity of this order, and so his revisional application was placed before the High Court

facts.text: Patna High Court held that stamp reporter's report correct, consistent with practice justified by Art.9

anchor.surface_text: The High Court took the view that the report made by the stamp reporter was companysistent with the practice which the High Court had followed in this matter and the said practice was fully justified by the provisions of Art 9.

facts.text: High Court rejected contention that no stamp needed on the two orders, directed affix stamps within two weeks

anchor.surface_text: In the result the companytention raised by the appellant that numberstamp need be affixed to the two orders was rejected and he was directed to affix the necessary stamps within two weeks from the date of the order.

facts.text: Appellant obtained certificate from High Court under Art.134(1)(c) Constitution for appeal to Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied for an obtained a certificate from the High Court under Art. 134 1  c  of the Constitution that the appellants case was fit for appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Appeal fought as test case to test validity of Patna High Court practice

anchor.surface_text: We have been told that this appeal is being fought as a test case in order to test the validity of the relevant practice prevailing in the Patna High Court.

facts.text: Appellant contends Art.9 construction does not require fees on certified copies of criminal orders

anchor.surface_text: It is with this certificate that the appellant has companye to this Court and on his behalf it has been urged by Mr. P. K. Chatterjee that the view taken by the Patna High Court is inconsistent with the true companystruction of Art. 9.

facts.text: CrPC s.173(4) requires free copy of police report, FIR, documents to accused before enquiry/trial

anchor.surface_text: Section 173 4  of the Code requires that before the companymencement of the enquiry or trial the officer in charge of the police station furnish or cause to be furnished to the accused free of companyt any companyy of the report forwarded under sub-s.  1  and of the First Information Report recorded under s. 154 and all other documents or relevant extracts thereof on which the prosecution proposes to rely.

facts.text: CrPC s.207A(3) requires magistrate to ensure s.173(4) complied with

anchor.surface_text: Section 207A, sub-s.  3  requires that the magistrate shall satisfy himself when the accused appears or is brought before him that the requirements of s. 173 4  have been duly companyplied with.

facts.text: CrPC s.210(2) provides free copy of charge to accused if required

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 210, sub-s.  2 , as soon as the charge is framed against the accused it shall be read and explained to him and a companyy thereof shall, if he so requires, be given to him free of companyt.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Patna HC view on Art.9 correct, copies of criminal orders require fees

anchor.surface_text: The words used in Art. 9 are clear and unambiguous, and in our opinion, on a fair and reasonable companystruction, they lead only to one companyclusion and that is that the companyies of the criminal judgments or orders must bear the companyrt fee stamp prescribed by Art. 9.

facts.text: Patna High Court practice on fees for copies consistent for several years

anchor.surface_text: That is the view taken by the High Court companysistently with the practice prevailing in the High Court for several years. We are satisfied that the view of the High Court and the practice prevailing there are wholly justified by the provisions of Art. 9.

facts.text: Travancore-Cochin High Court in James Paul Alexander v. James Arthur Edwards took same view on corresponding Art.10

anchor.surface_text: This question was raised before the Travancore-Cochin High Court in James Paul Alexander v. James Arthur Edwards I.L.R. 1953 T.C. 69, where the same view has been taken about the companystruction of the companyresponding article, Art. 10, of the Court Fees Act.

facts.text: Madras Legislature inserted Art.6-A in Sch.I Court Fees Act by Act V of 1922 for uniform fee of 8 as. on criminal court copies

anchor.surface_text: The Madras Legislature has inserted Art. 6-A in Sch. I of the Act by Act V of 1922, prescribing a uniform companyrt fee of 8 as. for the companyy or translation of a judgment or order of a criminal companyrt.

facts.text: Proceeding under s.107 CrPC is a judicial proceeding

anchor.surface_text: It cannot also be disputed that the proceeding in a criminal companyrt is a judicial proceeding. Section 4, sub-s.  m , of the Code of Criminal Procedure defines a judicial proceeding as including any proceeding in the companyrse of which evidence is, or may be, legally taken on oath.

facts.text: Orders in s.107 proceedings are orders in judicial proceeding not otherwise provided for in Act

anchor.surface_text: Thus there can be numberdoubt that an order passed in a criminal proceeding is an order passed in a judicial proceeding, and it is companymon ground that orders like those in the present appeal are number otherwise provided for by the Act.

issues.text: construction of Art. 9 in Sch. I of Court Fees Act VII of 1870

anchor.surface_text: the construction of Art. 9 in Sch. I of Court Fees Act VII of 1870  hereinafter called the Act . A proceeding was instituted

arguments.claim: The view taken by the Patna High Court is inconsistent with the true construction of Art. 9; certified copies of criminal court orders do not require court fees

anchor.surface_text: It is with this certificate that the appellant has come to this Court and on his behalf it has been urged by Mr. P. K. Chatterjee that the view taken by the Patna High Court is inconsistent with the true construction of Art. 9.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ecided solely by reference to the relevant provisions of the Act. In the companystruction of the said provisions any hypothetical companysiderations a

arguments.court_reasoning: Words of Art. 9 clear and unambiguous, lead only to conclusion that copies of criminal judgments/orders require fee

arguments.claim: In construing Art. 9, the policy of the CrPC providing free copies of documents to accused persons is relevant and argues against requiring court fees on certified copies of criminal orders

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chatterjee contends that in construing Art. 9 it would be relevant to bear in mind the policy which Legislature has deliberately adopted in enacting the material provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure dealing with the question of supplying to the accused persons requisite copies under the Code, Section 173 (4) of the Code requires that before the commencement of the enquiry or trial the officer

court_response_anchor.surface_text: rge of the police station furnish or cause to be furnished to the accused free of companyt any companyy of the report forwarded under sub-s.  1  and o

arguments.court_reasoning: Policy of CrPC irrelevant to construing Court Fees Act; applicability decided solely by provisions of the Act per s.4

arguments.claim: Provisions of Court Fees Act should be strictly construed in favour of the litigant; no document chargeable unless clearly falls within relevant provisions (liberal construction)

anchor.surface_text: It is also urged that the provisions of the Court Fees Act should be strictly construed in favour of the litigant and no document should be held chargeable with court fees unless it is clearly proved that it falls within the mischief of the relevant provisions of the Act. In other words, the appellants case is that we should adopt a liberal construction of Art. 9 in dealing with his present contention.

arguments.court_reasoning: Liberal construction inapplicable if words capable of only one construction; plain meaning governs even if inequitable

arguments.claim: Stamp reporter's report correct and consistent with High Court practice, which is justified by provisions of Art. 9; court fees required on certified copies

anchor.surface_text: The High Court took the view that the report made by the stamp reporter was consistent with the practice which the High Court had followed in this matter and the said practice was fully justified by the provisions of Art 9.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ecided solely by reference to the relevant provisions of the Act. In the companystruction of the said provisions any hypothetical companysiderations a

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court view and practice wholly justified by Art. 9

arguments.claim: Policy considerations from CrPC irrelevant to construction of Court Fees Act; document chargeability decided solely by Act's provisions per s.4

anchor.surface_text: We are not impressed by either of the two arguments. Whatever may be the policy on which the relevant provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure are based any consideration based on the said policy would not be of any assistance in construing the provisions of the Act. Section 4 of the Act provides that no document of any of the kinds specified in the First or Second Schedule

arguments.claim: Court Fees Act provisions not subject to liberal construction unless ambiguous; if plain meaning, must follow even if inequitable (citing Coltness Iron Co.)

anchor.surface_text: Similarly it would be idle to rely on the principle of liberal construction of Art. 9 unless it is shown that the said article is capable of two construction. If the words used in Art. 9 are reasonably capable of only one construction, the doctrine of liberal construction would be wholly out of place. Whether or not the effect of Art. 9 is equitable, fair or just would be irrelevant if the meaning of the article is plain and clear.

arguments.claim: Orders in s.107 CrPC proceedings are not covered by Art.6 or Art.7 Sch.I Court Fees Act

anchor.surface_text: Article 6 of Sch. I deals with the payment of court fees for a copy or translation of a judgment or order not being or having the force of a decree whereas Art. 7 deals with the copy of a decree. It is obvious that the orders with which we are concerned in the present appeal do not fall under either Art. 6 or Art. 7.

arguments.claim: Proceeding under s.107 CrPC is a judicial proceeding per CrPC s.4(m); orders therein are orders in judicial proceeding not otherwise provided for

anchor.surface_text: It cannot also be disputed that the proceeding in a criminal court is a judicial proceeding. Section 4, sub-s. (m), of the Code of Criminal Procedure defines a judicial proceeding as including any proceeding in the course of which evidence is, or may be, legally taken on oath. Thus there can be no doubt that an order passed in a criminal proceeding is an order passed in a judicial proceeding, and it is common ground that orders like those in the present appeal are not otherwise provided for by the Act.

arguments.claim: Copies of criminal court orders/judgments fall under Art.9 Sch.I Court Fees Act as copies of judicial proceedings/orders not otherwise provided for

anchor.surface_text: Art. 9 reads thus - ... It is clear that a copy of a statement or report or the like taken out of a criminal court is expressly provided for by the latter part of Art. 9 ... So, if a copy of an order or judgment delivered in a criminal proceeding is intended to be filed before the High Court it clearly attracts the provisions of Art. 9.

arguments.claim: Words of Art.9 clear and unambiguous; on fair construction, copies of criminal judgments/orders must bear prescribed court fee

anchor.surface_text: The words used in Art. 9 are clear and unambiguous, and in our opinion, on a fair and reasonable construction, they lead only to one conclusion and that is that the copies of the criminal judgments or orders must bear the court fee stamp prescribed by Art. 9.

arguments.claim: Patna High Court practice on fees for several years justified by Art.9

anchor.surface_text: That is the view taken by the High Court consistently with the practice prevailing in the High Court for several years. We are satisfied that the view of the High Court and the practice prevailing there are wholly justified by the provisions of Art. 9.

arguments.claim: Travancore-Cochin High Court in James Paul Alexander took same view on corresponding Art.10

anchor.surface_text: This question was raised before the Travancore-Cochin High Court in James Paul Alexander v. James Arthur Edwards I.L.R. 1953 T.C. 69, where the same view has been taken about the construction of the corresponding article, Art. 10, of the Court Fees Act.

holdings.text: The words used in Art. 9 are clear and unambiguous, and in our opinion, on a fair and reasonable construction, they lead only to one conclusion and that is that the copies of the criminal judgments or orders must bear the court fee stamp prescribed by Art. 9.

anchor.surface_text: The words used in Art. 9 are clear and unambiguous, and in our opinion, on a fair and reasonable construction, they lead only to one conclusion and that is that the copies of the criminal judgments or orders must bear the court

holdings.text: We are satisfied that the view of the High Court and the practice prevailing there are wholly justified by the provisions of Art. 9.

anchor.surface_text: That is the view taken by the High Court consistently with the practice prevailing in the High Court for several years. We are satisfied that the view of the High Court and the practice prevailing there are wholly justified by the provisions of Art. 9.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms Patna High Court decision and long-standing practice as consistent with clear text of Art. 9.
